content:
Âê≥ÊÅ©ÈÅî is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.

He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Fleeing and Some ImplicationsGrowing up in Stockton, Ca it‚Äôs never really surprising to hear about a police chase in where the suspect gets shot and then passes away. It‚Äôs not surprising when we hear of people fleeing from the police when the situation escalates. What is surprising to hear is when a law enforcement officer is prosecuted for the death of a fleeing sispect. In Georgia, a police officer had a fatal encounter with a man who was fleeing was charged with manslaughter. A police officer was charged for shooting and death of a teenager who fleed after a traffic stop.
This analysis is going to explore some of the different circumstances behind fatal police shootings in where the victim was fleeing.
Type of FleeingFigure 1 below shows the proportion of those who do not flee, who do, and if they are fleeing, what method of fleeing are these individuals using.
#proportion are killed while attempting to fleeshootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ flee + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(proportion = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot() +geom_line(mapping = aes(x = year, y = proportion, color = flee)) +ggtitle("Proportion of Fatal Police Shooting by Flee Method") + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion")Figure 1The proportion of fatal police shootings by flee method over time.
summary: Fleeing and Some ImplicationsGrowing up in Stockton, Ca it‚Äôs never really surprising to hear about a police chase in where the suspect gets shot and then passes away. It‚Äôs not surprising when we hear of people fleeing from the police when the situation escalates.
title: Looking at Fatal Police Shootings and Victims Fleeing

content:
Mental IllnessA statistic that many post on their social media stories cites that people with mental illness are 15 times more likely to be shot in a police encounter than the lay person. We can think about people like Shukri Ali Said who‚Äôs sister called 911 for aid when Said had a mental break. Police had found Said at an intersection with a knife and shot her 5 times, resulting in her death. We can think about Saheed Vassell. A man with a recorded mental illness, who also had a fatal police shooting. Vassell pointed a pipe at a police officer and was shot. We can think about the many people with mental and intellectual illnesses who had fatal police encounters and think about the possible different roots of the problem; the history of social stigma of treatment, to the processes of deinstitutionalization, to the defunding of existing community services like education, affordable housing, social and health services.
This post is going to explore the effects of mental illness and fatal police encounters.
General StatisticsYou can find the dataset here.
mental.illness <- shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ race + signs_of_mental_illness + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(race, signs_of_mental_illness) %>%summarise(mean = mean(count),sd = sd(count),min = min(count),max = max(count)) ## `summarise()` regrouping output by 'race' (override with `.groups` argument)d1 <- mental.illness %>%datatable()Table 1General descriptive statistics of fatal police shootings overall.
ag.year <- shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ race + signs_of_mental_illness + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(race, signs_of_mental_illness, year) %>%summarise(mean = mean(count))## `summarise()` regrouping output by 'race', 'signs_of_mental_illness' (override with `.groups` argument)d2 <- ag.year %>%datatable()ag.year %>%ggplot() +geom_point(mapping = aes(x = race, y = mean), color = "gray") +geom_boxplot(mapping = aes(x = race, y = mean, fill = signs_of_mental_illness)) +theme_bw() + ggtitle("Average Shootings by Mental Illness") + xlab("Race") + ylab("Average")Figure 1Boxplot of the mean fatal police encounters by race over the years.
Table 2Mean of police shooting by race aggregated by year.
In the two tables shown above, we get a good picture of the general look of fatal police encounters by signs of mental illness, from the years 2015 to current day. White people make up more than 70% of the US population, so it makes sense that white people will make up the most of police shootings in just raw numbers. Look at Figure 1 for the example. If we do some data crunching, we wil see something interesting. Since 2015, even though white people make up more than 70% of the population, 45% of fatal shootings involve white victims, which is disproportionate. If we factor in mental illness, overall, almost 30% of the white victims of fatal police shootings showed signs of mental illness. Of black victims: 14.3%, of asian: 24.7%, of hispanic: 17.2%, of native american: 17.9%. Overall, 28.9% of fatal police shooting victims are recorded as showing signs of mental illness.
Were there attempts of de-escalation?If more than 1 in 4 victims of fatal police shootings involve mental illness, were there attempts to subdue these victims besides shooting? The dataset I‚Äôm working with involve whether a taser was used to de-escalate along with shooting via the variable ‚Äòmanner_of_death‚Äô. There were only two categories, ‚Äúshot‚Äù, and, ‚Äúshot and Tasered‚Äù.
shootings %>%filter(signs_of_mental_illness == "True") %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ manner_of_death + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(prop = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot() +geom_line(mapping = aes(x = year, y = prop, color = manner_of_death)) +theme_bw() + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion") + ggtitle("Victims with Mental Illness")Figure 2
In figure 2, we see that with the fatal police shootings involving victims that showed signs of mental illness, less than 10% in every year have on record that the police tried to deploy a taser as a means of subduing the victim. we actually see a dip in 2018 and is slowly starting to rise again. We are only through a little more than half of the year, but this dataset is updated real time, so this graph will always be current.
shootings %>%filter(signs_of_mental_illness == "True", manner_of_death == "shot and Tasered") %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ manner_of_death + year + race, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(prop = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot() +geom_smooth(mapping = aes(x = year, y = prop, color = race)) +theme_bw() + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion") + ggtitle("Victims with Mental Illness by Race")Figure 3Taser deployed with victims showing signs of mental illness by race
Figure 3 offers more insight. Overall, through all years, white victims that involve deployment of a taser: 47.8%, native american: 1.11%, hispanic: 17.8%, black: 23.3%, asian: 3.3%. We also see that the proportion of the use and deployment of a taser is more steadily increasing among black and white victims, those who make up the majority of victims of fatal police shootings. The percentage of hispanic victims look to be increasing to a small degree, but it may be attributed to the decrease in proportion of victims with race not being recorded.
ConclusionWith almost 28.9% of all fatal police shootings involve the victims showing signs of mental illness. Of those instances, less than 10% every year are recorded that other means than just shooting a gun were used to subdue the victim. Figure 3 shows the ratio of those instances by race with white and black percentages increasing since 2018.
It still begs the question. If 28.9% of victims of fatal police shootings show signs of mental illness, why do 10% of those cases have other means besides shooting as a way to subdue these individuals? I do think it is important to note that certain states have banned the use of tasers. However, could these instances of mental breaks or threatening individuals with mental illnesses been avoided all together? Should we have invested more in social services and health services? These are questions that can‚Äôt be answered with this dataset alone.
summary: Mental IllnessA statistic that many post on their social media stories cites that people with mental illness are 15 times more likely to be shot in a police encounter than the lay person.
title: Exploration of Mental Illness and Fatal Police Shootings

content:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
```python import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() ```  renders as
import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head()  Charts Academic supports the popular Plotly chart format.
Save your Plotly JSON in your page folder, for example chart.json, and then add the {{< chart data="chart" >}} shortcode where you would like the chart to appear.
Demo:
  (function() { let a = setInterval( function() { if ( typeof window.Plotly === 'undefined' ) { return; } clearInterval( a ); Plotly.d3.json("./line-chart.json", function(chart) { Plotly.plot('chart-865491723', chart.data, chart.layout, {responsive: true}); }); }, 500 ); })();  You might also find the Plotly JSON Editor useful.
Math Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.
Example math block:
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |} {\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$  renders as
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$
Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.
Example multi-line math using the \\\\ math linebreak:
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\\\ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$  renders as
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
Diagrams Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.
An example flowchart:
```mermaid graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] ```  renders as
graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]  An example sequence diagram:
```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! ```  renders as
sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!  An example Gantt diagram:
```mermaid gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d ```  renders as
gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d  An example class diagram:
```mermaid classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } ```  renders as
classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() }  An example state diagram:
```mermaid stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] ```  renders as
stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]  Todo lists You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:
- [x] Write math example - [x] Write diagram example - [ ] Do something else  renders as
 Write math example Write diagram example Do something else  Tables Represent your data in tables:
| First Header | Second Header | | ------------- | ------------- | | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Content Cell | Content Cell |  renders as
   First Header Second Header     Content Cell Content Cell   Content Cell Content Cell    Callouts Academic supports a shortcode for callouts, also referred to as asides, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.
{{% alert note %}} A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers. {{% /alert %}}  renders as
 A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.   Spoilers Add a spoiler to a page to reveal text, such as an answer to a question, after a button is clicked.
{{< spoiler text="Click to view the spoiler" >}} You found me! {{< /spoiler >}}  renders as
 Click to view the spoiler  You found me!    Icons Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.
Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:
{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal {{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python {{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R  renders as
  Terminal
 Python
 R
Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it üôå
summary:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
title: Writing technical content in Academic

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

title: External Project
